text.title: Lício Velloso
text.p:
Licio
Augusto
Velloso
is a Brazilian full professor of
medicine
at the
University of Campinas
.

p.s: Lício Velloso obtained his MD degree in 1986 from the University of Campinas .

He then attended
Uppsala University
in Sweden from which he graduated in 1993 and then served as a postdoc at the Mario Saad Lab , University of Campinas and at the Ron Kahn Lab ,
Harvard University
in 1994 and 1995 respectively .
[ 1 ]

He also was postdoctoral
fellow
at the
Joslin Diabetes Center
[ 2 ]
and is coordinator of the Obesity and Comorbidities Research Center at the University of Campinas .
[ 3 ]
In 2001 he studied type 2 diabetes along with Claudio Teodoro de Souza , a back-then Ph.D. student at the Cell Signaling Laboratory .

Their study revealed that the disease reoccurs when
pancreas
fail to supply the peripheral need for
insulin
that the body needs .
According to Lício Velloso , as long as the pancreas can produce insulin to maintain this need , the blood glucose level remains stable - close to 80 , 90 , expected for a healthy person .
But , when it does fail , the glucose rises , which makes a patient dependent on insulin .

This dependency can result into
hyperinsulinemic hypoglycemia
, according to Velloso .
Under Velloso 's guidance , Souza had studied alpha protein and injected it with an insulin-producing cell .

While the result did n't yield a major breakthrough , it opened a possibility of developing a drug that would reduce the action of
PPARGC1A
.
During the trials , which the duo conducted revealed that it does indeed reduces the production of alpha protein while increases insulin production .

Not only did it increase insulin production , but it also decrease diabetes occurrence .
[ 4 ]

For two years , he and
Marciane Milanski
, a nutritionist , had studied
obesity
in
rats
.
During the study , it was suggested that it is possible to make brain control liver in order to maintain glycemic balance .

When it does happen , the
hypothalamus
becomes the main actor of this mechanism .
The research , along with his comment : " The mechanism described by this research shows that control of high glucose in fasting is done , at least in part , by the hypothalamus .

This reinforces our suspicion that the development of drugs with action in the central nervous system should be interesting for the treatment of diabetes " were published in the
American Journal of Deabetes
in 2012 .
[ 5 ]

From 2005 to 2007 he had studied human diet , and , according to him , the studies of various groups have shown that a diet rich in simple
carbohydrates
, can also increase
lipid
levels in the
blood
and indirectly promote
inflammation
in the
hypothalamus
.
[ 3 ]
In 2018 Lício Velloso studied hunger strikes and divided them in three categories : Absolute , total and partial .
During the study , he suggested that people who do partial hunger strikes could have more severe consequences then those that have the absolute one .

For example , in an absolute strike only
kidneys
and
heart
fails after 25 days of being on a strike , while strikers who preferred partial ended up with liver complications within 40 to 50 days after the strike .

In conclusion , what Dr. Velloso suggests is that people who have a weak heart should n't take too much liquid , otherwise it can lead to heart failure and even death .
[ 6 ]

On October 30 , 2018 he appeared on an interview with Paulo Saldiva of Science and Health program of the Futura Chanel .
[ 7 ]

He is a former member of the
editorial board
of
Clinical Endocrinology
and current member of the editorial board of
International Journal of Obesity
.
[ 8 ]
